title: Review
text:
This app has been really helpful in reducing my screen time. This is the first one that I‚Äôve used that I‚Äôve stuck with for more then a couple days. Some of my favorite features include the weekly screen time report and telling me how many years of my life I‚Äôm getting back by reducing my screen time. Seeing the hours I spend on my phone added up into years gives me the perspective I need to stay motivated. Additionally I really enjoy the mini activities intended to give you a dopamine hit. There have been a couple times that I‚Äôve put down my phone afterward instead of unlocking social media. There are several glitches in the app although an update was just released and may have addressed the issues. 

Side note: This app relies heavily on AI from my knowledge which makes me fairly uncomfortable. Although I made the choice to use this app my primary complaint about the AI is cynical language used in the game section intended to provide dopamine. I understand that it would be unreasonable to ask the company to remove the AI from the app but I do not want to engage this kind of language for no reason, especially in this section of the app I just completed a game that asks you to do basic math equations (addition and subtraction) and race against AI. I lost two times in a row and both times the app told me that the AI won and ‚ÄúHumanity is doomed‚Äù.  This kind of language and narrative encourages me not to use this app. If this expands to other parts of the app, I will likely cancel my subscription. I have enough other apps I can go on to have an existential crisis, I don‚Äôt need my screen time app to be added to that list.
Worth it, paying is optional and you can control how much restriction you want, has helped me save hours

title: Had to delete. Too many bugs.
text:
While I do think that blocking apps is an easy way to slowly cure my phone addiction, this app caused me too much stress due to its flaws. üëéüèº
When I tried to block most of my apps, I obviously made an exception for the ones that were absolutely necessary. When I check the settings of the session on Opal, it says that they're not blocked, but when I try to click on it, it won't let me, demonstrating that the app has a clear flaw or bug. Why would it say my app isn't blocked when it clearly is? I thought deleting it and reinstalling it would help, but after a day, Opal went right back to blocking it alongside the rest of the apps. This is extremely frustrating because it made me unable to access the apps that are crucial to my day to day life, unless I stopped the session completely, freeing all of the apps that I'm trying to limit in my life, so what is the point of using Opal then? It honestly wouldn't be such an issue if it wasn't for the second flaw I kept experiencing; when I tried to take a Break from my session, I kept experiencing some sort of weird glitch, I would click to take a Break so I can use my important app, and Opal wouldn't do it. Each and every single time I tried to unlock my apps, I would have to do the process 2-3 times in order for it to work, which is annoying because obviously Opal makes you wait a few seconds/do a puzzle before you can get the option to unlock your apps. At one point, it simply wouldn't work and I didn't have the option to be patient with it because I had to use my crucial app in order to go about my business, I had no time to deal with the glitches and the puzzles. I deleted Opal and I have to learn to deal with my addiction in a different way. It's hard because I am constantly caught in the loop of consuming content and forgetting what I initially grabbed my phone for, but I am being forced to be more self aware and recognize how the endless scrolling starts, and the mechanisms that occur in my brain that I need to work on to finally be free from this addiction. So thanks for that, I guess I will have to grow to be more disciplined. But I was incredibly disappointed in Opal's glitches that I don't think I will ever download this app again unless it is resolved. I do see know value that it can have if it is functional, though.

title: Strong blocking, but missing real accountability
text:
This app does a good job enforcing Screen Time limits, but it falls short as an accountability tool.

Like most Screen Time apps, it relies on three mechanisms:
‚Ä¢app time limits
‚Ä¢unlocks / temporary access
‚Ä¢scheduled blocks

The problem is that following or breaking these rules isn‚Äôt meaningfully tracked. Users can:
‚Ä¢repeatedly use unlocks
‚Ä¢change limits or schedules after enforcement starts
‚Ä¢revoke Screen Time permissions and re-enable later

‚Ä¶without any persistent history or consequence inside the app. That makes it easy to undermine your own rules quietly, which defeats the purpose for serious users.

What would make this a 5-star app:
‚Ä¢an accountability history (unlock usage, schedule adherence, rule changes)
‚Ä¢logging Screen Time permission revocations/restores
‚Ä¢an integrity metric (did I keep my word or not)
‚Ä¢brief, optional reflection prompts at key moments (before unlocks, after rule changes)
‚Ä¢weekly summaries focused on accountability, not just usage minutes
‚Ä¢a place to define and revisit why you‚Äôre limiting apps, so behavior change is internal, not just enforced

Blocking alone changes behavior temporarily.
Accountability, integrity tracking, and reflection change it long-term.

If these additions were made, this would easily be a 5-star app.
